If you decrease the burst of one auto attack, but added more than the difference to the damage of the next auto attack, you can have a higher burst within a two auto attack period (generally less than 1 second of real-time) despite a lower hit per crit.  IE passively doubling crit chance does just that.  

Instead of 20-50-80% crit, it will be 0-60%-120%, so they have 10% more crit at 2 items, and 20% more crit at 3, for a slight loss in overall damage multiplier.  However, when you look at the effect of an attack on average from a sufficiently large set of attacks, it will actually increase the average damage against targets with more than 100 armor (less than tanks/juggernauts base armor for reference, or any squishy with as little as 20 extra armor.  You get ninja tabi, or a GA, and you'll take more damage after their ADC has 3 items than you would before the changes, no matter what champion you're playing.  Even a fucking Ashe or Cait. )

And the person you are responding to has the same maths I have seen.

Going from 80% crit and a 2.5 crit multiplier gives you an average of 

.80(2.5AD) for crits + .20(1.0AD) for non-crits, giving you 2.0 + .2 or 2.2 total AD scaling on average.

New IE doubles crit chance, so with 1 zeal its 60% crit chance, and with 2 its over capped beyond 100%, but you lose out on the 50% extra crit damage to instead convert 20% of the crit to true damage.

so with 1 zeal its .60(1.6AD) physical damage + .60(.4AD) true damage for crits + .40(1.0AD) for non-crits or 1.36AD physical damage and .24AD true damage (1.6 AD ratio, with 15% of the damage being true damage).

With 2 zeals its 1.0(1.6AD) physical damage and 1.0(.4AD) true damage, and everything ever is a crit.

So, like them, all I can see is the difference being -200 gold, + 10 AD and being far better against every single champion in the game, who all have more base armor than the break even point.

The difference is 1.6-2.2AD physical damage + .4AD true damage.  This simplifies to -.6AD physical damage to .4AD true damage.

We set them equal to each other.  .6AD physical = .4AD true.  this occurs when the physical damage multiplier is .6666_ (pretend that underscore is a vinculum)

The physical damage multiplier comes from armor and is equal to (100/100+armor) if armor is a positive number.

.6666 = 100/100+x.

The two solutions to this are x = -100 (which doesn't work because our armor formula is a piecewise function, that actually changes if x or our armor value, is negative) or x = 51.5151515_ (another vinculum)

Really, this means new IE will be better at 52 armor or more.  Every champion except Thresh has much higher base armor than this and he gets .75 per soul anyway.  Ashe and Cait have just over 80 armor at 18 for example, and almost no one is below 70.  By levels 10 or so, most champions have higher base armor than the break even point for the new IE, and it is literally half the base armor of tanks and juggernauts.

>also riot wants to nerf BURST AGAINST SQUISHIES not dps, so 100% crit or 80% crit doesn't matter in a burst scenario

I heavily disagree with this statement as it is completely ridiled in poor definitions, assumptions, or entire missing premises.

Burst occurs over a specified time table.  As we have not defined the time table, and ADCs can get 2.5 attacks off per second (or even more with PtA and new items coming in).  If the burst window was defined as a 1 second interval, which is about the lowest it can even make sense to limit it to, that still allows for ADCs to get off between as many as 2.5 and 5.0 attacks depending upon the set up, or in mid game, a more realistic 1.5 - 2 times.

If we set it at 2 seconds, or the length of a moderate CC, then the ADCs could conceivably be attacking from 3 times at the low end, to almost 10 times at the upper end with PtA abuse.

In all of these scenarios, literally any scenario with above 1 attack happening, that difference in critical strike chance really, truly matters, as it functions as a multiplier of crit damage, attack speed, and AD, worth exponentially more the more of the other stats you have.  You're effectively ignoring a fifth of their entire damage potential by not factoring in the difference between 80% and 100% critical strike chance.
